High-redshift SMBHs can grow from stellar-mass seeds via chaotic
accretion

ever tighter constraints on the formation and growth mechanisms of early black holes. Here we show that even the most extreme

that accretion proceeds almost continuously, but is composed of a large number of episodes with individually-uncorrelated
initial directions. This chaotic accretion scenario ensures that the growing black hole spins slowly, with the dimensionless

It is now generally accepted that most galaxies harbour supermas-
sive black holes (SMBHs) in their centres (Merloni & Heinz 2013;

Graham 2016). This is true both for galaxies in the Local Universe
and at high redshift, where almost 200 quasars have been discovered
at

6 (Willott et al. 2010; Carnall et al. 2015; Matsuoka et al.
2016; BaÃ±ados et al. 2016; Jiang et al. 2016; Mazzucchelli et al.
2017; Reed et al. 2017; Wang et al. 2017; Matsuoka et al. 2018a,b;
Reed et al. 2019; Wang et al. 2019; Vito et al. 2019). These quasars
are typically powered by SMBHs with masses of order 10

, yet
are seen at lookback times

13 Gyr, i.e. when the Universe was
less than 800 Myr old. The most extreme SMBH currently known is
PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena with a mass of

.
These observations provide a rather tight constraint on the possible
models of the origin and early growth of SMBHs.

these models fall broadly into two groups (see
Inayoshi et al. 2019, for a review). One group considers SMBHs

growing from massive seeds: objects with masses

(Ferrara et al. 2014) that form via direct gas collapse (Loeb & Rasio
1994; Begelman et al. 2006; DÄ³kstra et al. 2014; Chon et al.
2016; Wise et al. 2019), an intermediate supermassive star stage
(Regan & Haehnelt 2009; Volonteri & Begelman 2010; Begelman

2010) or due to rapid mergers of stars and/or individual stellar-mass
black holes in a dense cluster (Portegies Zwart & McMillan 2002;
Portegies Zwart et al. 2004; Devecchi & Volonteri 2009). These
seeds can then grow the required four orders of magnitude in mass
over several hundred Myr even if the radiative eï¬ƒciency of accretion
is

The second kind of model suggests that SMBHs grow from stellar-
mass seeds (Madau & Rees 2001) via luminous accretion with a
rather low radiative eï¬ƒciency. Low eï¬ƒciency may be achieved if

accretion rates are hyper-Eddington; they create conditions where
the photons emitted by the accreting gas cannot escape the accretion
ï¬‚ow and are dragged into the black hole (Alexander & Natarajan
2014; SÄ…dowski et al. 2015; Pacucci et al. 2015; Inayoshi et al. 2016;
Sakurai et al. 2016; Takeo et al. 2020). Even if accretion consists
of Eddington-limited thin disc episodes, a radiative eï¬ƒciency

06 may be achieved if the spin of the black hole is kept low (e.g.
King et al. 2008). Since the black hole mass depends exponentially

, this diï¬€erence is enough to allow for the growth of
SMBHs powering even the most extreme high-redshift quasars.

The evolution of the SMBH spin during a series of accretion
episodes depends on how the disc aligns with the hole. Early calcu-
lations (e.g. Thorne 1974; Scheuer & Feiler 1996) suggested that the
disc always aligns stably, and so the hole should be rapidly spun up to
almost the maximum possible spin,

is the dimen-
sionless spin parameter, with

0 representing a Schwarzschild
black hole and

1 representing a maximally-spinning Kerr black
hole. However, the conclusion of stable alignment rests on the erro-
neous implicit assumption that the disc angular momentum domi-
nates over that of the hole; in reality, the opposite is often the case,
and so stable counter-alignment may occur during many accretion
episodes (King et al. 2005). In these cases, accretion reduces SMBH
spin (King et al. 2005). A single counter-aligned accretion episode
reduces the spin much more than a single aligned episode increases
it, leading to a tendency for the SMBH spin to decrease over time
(King et al. 2008), provided that accretion is chaotic, i.e. individ-
ual accretion episodes have uncorrelated initial directions of angular
momentum. Numerical modelling of the evolution of SMBHs un-

der realistic cosmological conditions (e.g. Griï¬ƒn et al. 2019) mostly
conï¬rms this idea, although they do not produce large enough pop-
ulations to test for the presence of extreme high-redshift SMBHs.

In this paper, we investigate whether a chaotic accretion scenario
can produce extremely massive SMBHs at

800 Myr after the Big
Bang (corresponding to

7). We show that as long as accretion
events are not strongly correlated (

20% of all accretion events
happen along the same axis) and assuming a duty cycle close to 100%,
a PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena -like SMBH can be produced. This suggests that the
extreme quasars might be powered by accretion on to SMBHs with
rather unique growth histories, but such SMBHs are much more likely
to be observed at high redshift. We suggest ways to test our model, in
particular by searching for lower-mass and/or higher-redshift SMBHs
than the current extreme ones. We also predict that these extreme
SMBHs have rather low spins and should be signiï¬cantly obscured.
The paper is structured as follows. We begin by exploring the con-
straints on SMBH seed mass and radiative eï¬ƒciency provided by the
observations of extreme quasars in Section 2. In Section 3, we brieï¬‚y
describe the chaotic accretion model and its numerical implementa-
tion. In Section 4, we present the results of numerical calculations
of SMBH growth. We discuss their implications in Section 5 and
summarize in Section 6.
Throughout the paper, we use the most recent Planck cosmology

40, bringing even the most extreme quasars within reach of growth
models based on almost continuous accretion on to stellar mass

of uncertainty in observational constraints of

The model we use follows the one presented in King et al. (2005);
King & Pringle (2006, 2007); King et al. (2008). Here we only
present the basic qualitative arguments and refer the reader to those
papers for more details.

A SMBH grows via a series of individual accretion episodes. The
maximum mass that can be accreted during a single episode is given
by the self-gravity condition (cf. Pringle 1981)
is the disc aspect ratio and the factor 1

represents
the fraction of disc mass lost to radiation. The radiative eï¬ƒciency
depends monotonously on the dimensionless spin parameter

: for a
disc counter-aligned with a maximally spinning black hole,

057; and for prograde alignment between the disc and a
maximally spinning black hole,

Each accretion episode initially forms a disc with an angular mo-
mentum

to the direction of the holeâ€™s angular
momentum

. King et al. (2005) showed that the disc can align sta-
bly with the black hole in either a prograde or retrograde fashion,
with the latter case occuring if

Since the disc mass is always much smaller than the hole mass, as
long as the hole is not spinning very slowly, stable counter-alignment
might occur in close to half of all accretion episodes.

As the accretion disc evolves, most of its angular momentum
is transferred to large radii and eventually escapes the system
(Shakura & Sunyaev 1973; Pringle 1981). The angular momentum
actually transferred to the SMBH is

is the angular momentum of
gas per unit mass at the innermost stable circular orbit. The sign of

is positive if the disc is aligned with the SMBH and negative if
it is counter-aligned.

Over a large number of individual accretion episodes, the SMBH
spin evolves in a stochastic fashion. If the episodes are uncorrelated,
i.e. the initial direction of

is random for each episode, the trend is
for the spin to decrease, because a counter-rotating disc has a signif-

for a maximally
spinning black hole) than a prograde disc (

for
a maximally spinning black hole); as a result, the accreted angular
momentum is much greater in counter-aligned accretion events. On
the other hand, if the accretion episodes are correlated to some ex-
tent, the SMBH gradually begins to spin in the same direction and
its spin value increases.

We test the evolution of black hole mass and spin, as well as the
ï¬nal SMBH mass distributions, under various accretion alignment
conditions, using a numerical model. The model is initialised with a
seed black hole of mass

, with a random spin magnitude
and direction. A series of accretion events are then used to grow the
SMBH. Each event is limited in mass by the self-gravity condition
(eq. 3); we also checked that imposing an additional maximum mass
of an individual event, to simulate the possible mass limit of gas
clouds feeding the SMBH, has no eï¬€ect on our results. The initial
direction of the discâ€™s spin is chosen completely randomly in one
model; in two others, we add an additional parameter

4, and randomly select this fraction of accretion events to have
spins aligned in the positive-z direction. The code then checks the

condition for hole-disc alignment (eq. 4) and calculates the new
direction of the holeâ€™s angular momentum by considering the vector
sum of

. The mass and angular momentum of the black hole
are updated by adding the appropriate fractions of the disc mass (eq.
3) and angular momentum (eq. 5). The new angular momentum is
used to calculate the spin parameter and the radiative eï¬ƒciency to be
used for the next accretion event. The duration of a single episode is
calculated as the time for the AGN to consume the disc mass at the
given luminosity:

We set the luminosity to be equal to the Eddington luminosity of the
black hole. While the luminosity is likely to vary a lot during SMBH
growth, we are mainly interested in the early Universe and in extreme
black holes which are likely to have grown in dense gas environments
where prolonged feeding at the Eddington (or higher) rate was com-
mon. If the black hole is fed at a mildly super-Eddington rate, the ac-
cretion disc sheds material at radii larger than ISCO and the black hole

2, while
the mass grows exponentially and reaches the mass of PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena in

aï¬€ected. Models with partially aligned accretion events show higher
SMBH spins and, as a result, slower mass growth. In the model with

Despite the diï¬€erence in individual accretion episode directions,
both the overall spin and mass evolutions show remarkably similar
trends. However, with more alignment, the diï¬€erence in SMBH mass
between the two example models at a given time increases. In order to
show these diï¬€erences in more detail, as well as the range of SMBH

masses we may expect at diï¬€erent times in diï¬€erent scenarios, we
plot, in Figure 3, the histograms of SMBH masses in the three models
at

400, 500, 600 and 700 Myr accretion time. Each histogram is
produced by running the model 50 times with diï¬€erent sets of random
numbers determining the initial disc angular momentum direction.
The vertical dotted lines show the mean value of each histogram.

The variance of ï¬nal SMBH masses grows with increasing align-
ment of accretion events. In the purely chaotic case (top panels), the
diï¬€erence between the most- and least-massive SMBHs is a factor 2,
while in the most aligned case (bottom panels), it is a factor 10. This
happens because when the SMBH spin is higher, radiative eï¬ƒciency
is more sensitive to spin, leading to small changes in spin value
resulting in more signiï¬cant changes in SMBH growth rate. These
variations, are, of course, only lower limits on the actual spread of
SMBH masses at any given time, because we do not account for the
diï¬€erent duty cycles of individual black holes.

Our results show that it is possible to grow a black hole from a
stellar-mass seed to the size of PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena in

520 Myr, i.e.
rapidly enough to produce the black hole assuming that the ï¬rst stars
formed 180 Myr after the Big Bang (Bowman et al. 2018) or earlier.
Such a scenario rests on several implicit assumptions and produces
several predictions regarding the properties of high-redshift extreme
SMBHs and their eï¬€ect on the environment. We consider them in
turn.
5.1 Masses and alignment of individual accretion discs

The time coordinate in our models is the accretion time rather than
total time of the black holeâ€™s existence. So the fact that

520 Myr
is required for production of a PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena -mass SMBH means that
the duty cycle of its growth has to be almost 100%. This may be unre-
alistic combined with the necessity of having a low rate of alignment
of accretion directions; in fact, one might expect accretion direc-
tions to be highly correlated if accretion is essentially continuous.
Nevertheless, there are several ways of mitigating this tension.

The masses of individual accretion episodes in our model are
limited by the self-gravity condition (Pringle 1981; King & Pringle
2007). The validity of this condition rests on two assumptions: that

the disc is geometrically thin and optically thick, i.e. that the standard
thin-disc equations are applicable to describing its structure, and that
cooling is eï¬ƒcient at radii

is
the Schwarzschild radius of the SMBH. Thin discs are the stan-
dard solution describing an accretion ï¬‚ow with mass ï¬‚ow rate

2013; Inayoshi et al. 2016). The importance of self-gravity in the
outer regions of these discs has been recognised by numerous au-
thors (e.g., Shlosman et al. 1990; Gammie 2001; Rice et al. 2005).
In addition, cooling is typically eï¬ƒcient in these regions and leads to
star formation (Shlosman & Begelman 1989; Collin & Zahn 1999;
Goodman 2003); even if the forming stars heat the disc up and

prevent further fragmentation, this does not shut oï¬€ the growth of
these stars (Nayakshin 2006). The stellar rings around Sgr A

, the
central SMBH of the Milky Way, provide strong evidence for the
validity of this scenario (Paumard et al. 2006; Bonnell & Rice 2008;
Bartko et al. 2009). Cooling in primordial accretion discs is probably
less eï¬ƒcient due to low metallicity, but this is unlikely to stabilize
them signiï¬cantly against self-gravity (Tanaka & Omukai 2014).
High-z SMBHs can grow from stellar seeds
5.2 Gas reservoir mass and accretion duty cycle

The gas reservoir surrounding the SMBH is likely to be turbulent,
perhaps composed of streams and orbiting clumps. In this case, the
streams of gas approaching the SMBH may easily have diï¬€erent
directions, even if the reservoir as a whole has some angular momen-
tum. The radius of the feeding reservoir immediately available to the
SMBH is

, the radius of inï¬‚uence of the black holeâ€™s gravity
(Dehnen & King 2013), which is much higher than the maximum ra-
dius of a non-self-gravitating accretion disc. As a result, even a small
diï¬€erence in the impact parameter of two streams falling toward the
SMBH will lead to signiï¬cant diï¬€erences in the angle of the form-
ing disc (Nayakshin et al. 2012). This suggests that even essentially
continuous accretion can be almost entirely chaotic.

Streams falling in from various directions also continuously
change the orientation of the accretion disc. This happens on ap-
proximately the dynamical timescale of the reservoir,
where we scale the reservoir size to 100 pc and the velocity dispersion

. This should have little eï¬€ect on the initial alignment
between the disc and the hole, because only the warped region of the

, the warp radius is
disc is aï¬€ected by this. So long as

smaller than the self-gravity radius and the initial alignment between
the black hole and the disc is not aï¬€ected by the outer regions of the
disc.

Some galaxies have disky structures surrounding their cen-
tral SMBHs on scales of order 0

1 pc, e.g. NGC 4258
(Herrnstein et al. 2005), IC 2560 (Yamauchi et al. 2012) and NGC
1068 (Imanishi et al. 2020). Although these are almost certainly
strongly self-gravitating systems (e.g., Kumar 1999; Lodato & Bertin
2003; Martin 2008; Tilak et al. 2008), we can consider, for the sake
of argument, what happens if such systems are prevented from frag-
menting. Over time, the accretion disc aligns with the black hole
in a prograde fashion. However, this this happens on the viscous
timescale at the radius where the disc angular momentum starts to
dominate over that of the hole, which is (cf. King et al. 2005)
is the black hole mass scaled to 10

and assuming
Eddington-rate accretion. The ratio between the two timescales is

This ratio is much lower than unity except for the smallest black holes,
and even then only if the feeding reservoir is as large as 100 pc. If
the black hole is initially fed inside a cloud with radius

24 pc,
the dynamical timescale is shorter than the alignment timescale even
for a 10 M

seed black hole. As a result, new gas streams eï¬€ectively
randomize the direction of the accretion disc much faster than the
disc can cause the SMBH to align with it.

The reservoir is depleted by accretion and small-scale momentum-
driven feedback, but outï¬‚ows are unlikely to aï¬€ect dense gas outside
of the sphere of inï¬‚uence for as long as the SMBH mass is lower than

mass (King 2010). The depleted reservoir is contin-
uously reï¬lled by gas falling in from larger distances throughout the
host halo. Assuming that the halo is gas-rich, as appropriate for high
redshift, the infall rate may be a signiï¬cant fraction of the dynamical
rate (cf. Dehnen & King 2013)
where we scale the gas fraction

. This rate is much higher
than the Eddington accretion rate even for a SMBH with the mass
equivalent to PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena . Considering that the most massive black
holes should reside in haloes with the highest velocity dispersion,
reï¬lling the reservoir surrounding the black hole is even easier.

, is also rather conservative. It
is comparable to that expected for supernova remnants of present-day
stars. Early, Population III, stars are expected to be more massive on
average than present-day ones (Hirano et al. 2014; Susa et al. 2014;
Stacy et al. 2016); as a result, their explosion remnants might be more
massive as well. The ï¬nal mass of the black hole at any given time
is approximately proportional to the seed mass, so a more massive
seed makes it slightly easier to grow an extremely massive SMBH
quickly. Furthermore, the eï¬€ective seed mass might be higher if the
black hole forms in a cluster and merges with a few other similar
black holes while its mass is still small. However, the constraint on

SMBH spin, and hence on the maximum level of alignment, hardly
changes if we assume higher seed masses - this can be seen in Figure
1.

Our model is insensitive to the precise redshift of the formation
of the black hole seed. In principle, even a seed forming as late as at

180 Myr after the Big Bang, can give
rise to PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena , provided that it maintains a duty cycle

The possibilities described in sections 5.1 - 5.3 allow for some vari-
ation of model parameters, but the observational constraints are still
tight. They also provide a stringent test for our model. In particular,
the model would be falsiï¬ed if an SMBH would be detected at a time

545 Myr after the Big Bang,
or, equivalently,

6 Myr corre-
sponds to the purely chaotic SMBH growth model, and we use the

for this estimate. Quasars powered by
such SMBHs - if they exist - should be discovered by upcoming

(Nandra et al. 2013; Aird et al. 2013)
missions. Discoveries of slightly less extreme SMBHs, including that
of PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena , provide constraints on parameter combinations en-
compassing the seed black hole mass, duty cycle, formation time and
alignment fraction of accretion episodes.

most 100% duty cycle for these objects, the space density of SMBHs

The rate of formation of the ï¬rst stars is estimated at

20 (Johnson et al. 2008); this

Assuming that the seeds of the most extreme quasars must have been
produced before

180 Myr, leaving
520 Myr for PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena to grow), this gives

80 Myr for seed
formation. Over this period, even the most conservative estimate pro-
vides a seed BH density

, and it is possible that
this density was at least an order of magnitude higher. These val-

ues are consistent with estimates based on numerical modelling of
Population III star formation (Madau & Rees 2001; Volonteri 2010).
Comparing this value with the quasar space density, we see that if
only one in 4

of initial seeds encounters favourable growth
conditions, the population of extreme quasars observed at

This result suggests an explanation for the issue of â€˜stellar black
hole starvationâ€™, which is expected at high redshifts (e.g. Pacucci et al.
2015, 2017; Smith et al. 2018). It happens due to two reasons:
many nascent stellar black holes can be ejected from their parent
star-forming halos (Whalen & Fryer 2012), and those that remain
cannot accrete material eï¬ƒciently until the fossil HII region that
surrounded the progenitor star cools down (Johnson et al. 2007).
However, a small fraction of black holes can avoid these issues if
they are born within a larger protogalactic halo with escape velocity

allows the black hole
to escape the fossil HII region very quickly. Small-scale feedback
can enhance gas mixing (Dehnen & King 2013) and suppress frag-
mentation (Alvarez et al. 2009) around these black holes, promoting
accretion at near-Eddington rates. The expected rarity of these ob-
jects can also explain why they are not reproduced in numerical and
semi-analytical simulations (Smith et al. 2018; Griï¬ƒn et al. 2019).

We expect that the key parameters determining the growth rate
of the SMBH vary smoothly over their allowed range; furthermore,
there are no discontinuities or sharp changes in the dependence of the
ï¬nal SMBH mass on these parameters. Due to this, we predict that
the mass function of black holes, and of quasars, should be approxi-
mately continuous in mass/luminosity, consistent with available ob-
servational constraints. However, the slope of the mass function may
be very shallow, i.e. the density of less massive black holes might
not be much higher than that of the most massive ones. The total
X-ray radiation produced by high-redshift quasars suggests that lu-
minous accretion contributed only

10% of this limit. This means that the smaller black holes cannot
have grown very much at these early times. In addition, the lower
duty cycle of these smaller black holes means that the

den-
sity is signiï¬cantly lower than the SMBH density. These two factors
might explain why the smaller SMBHs at high redshift have not been
detected yet.

Our results provide two important and potentially testable predictions
regarding the properties of extreme high-redshift SMBHs: their spins
must be low and they should reside in dense gas environments.

Typical spins of black holes growing through purely chaotic ac-
cretion settle to

350 Myr. At this time, the black
hole mass is only

aligned with

or higher. If accretion is aligned more, the black
hole does not reach a mass of 10

over 600 Myr of accretion.
So the most massive black holes, those with

700 Myr old or younger, should all have
spins lower than

5. Among more moderate black holes, with
10

, the spin distribution should be wide, with
both low and high spin values possible. Black holes with masses

should generally spin rapidly, although low spin val-
ues should be possible in this population as well. This contrasts with
available observational constraints on SMBHs in the Local Universe,
where black holes with masses

seem to have spin
values close to maximal, and even more massive black holes gen-
erally have spins

There are a few ways of reconciling our prediction with the
observationally-estimated spins. First of all, the observed high-
redshift quasars represent an extreme population (see Section 5.5)
and their spins need not be representative of the high-redshift pop-
ulation as a whole. We predict that as SMBHs with more mod-
est masses are discovered at high redshift, and as their spin esti-
mates are obtained, the overall population will come to resemble
the locally-observed one more closely, even if not exactly. Secondly,
the global mass growth of supermassive black holes is expected to
be dominated by mergers since

5, i.e. for the past 3-4 Gyr
(Bassini et al. 2019). Mergers tend to ï¬‚atten the spin distribution
(Berti & Volonteri 2008), so even if the extreme quasars have spins
representative of the early SMBH population as a whole, the lo-
cal population will have much more broadly distributed spin values.
There is tentative observational evidence, based on the evolution
AGN jet power, that the typical spins have been increasing at least
since

1 (MartÃ­nez-Sansigre & Rawlings 2011). Finally, observa-
tional biases lead to easier identiï¬cation of AGN powered by rapidly
spinning SMBHs, and the currently observed population is consis-
tent with a non-negligible number of slowly-spinning black holes

(Vasudevan et al. 2016). The situation should become signiï¬cantly
clearer once the so-far elusive low mass SMBH population at high
redshifts will be discovered, with upcoming observatories such as

(Green et al. 2012). In addi-
tion, future missions, including

(Mushotzky et al. 2019), will be able to measure SMBH spins
with unprecedented precision even at high redshift, providing better
constraints on the evolution of this quantity.

As spin determines radiative eï¬ƒciency, information about quasar
luminosity might also be used to put constraints on black hole spin.

Our models are consistent with the general expectation of nu-
the most massive SMBHs should be
merical simulations that
found in dense environments (Overzier et al. 2009; Costa et al. 2014;
Habouzit et al. 2019). Some observational campaigns conï¬rm this
(e.g., Kim et al. 2009; Husband et al. 2013), while others donâ€™t
(Morselli et al. 2014; Mazzucchelli et al. 2017). The discrepancy in

results may arise due to various selection eï¬€ects, low-number statis-
tics and stochasticity (Buchner et al. 2019). In addition, the host
galaxies of high-redshift quasars tend to have very high star for-
mation rates (SFR; Trakhtenbrot et al. 2017; Decarli et al. 2018),
indicating high gas content. The reason for this correlation in our
model is the requirement of a massive gas reservoir that can feed
the SMBH while withstanding AGN feedback; in some cases, this
feedback may be positive and induce a part of the observed high SFR.
In contrast, other SMBH origin models require the seeds to form in
the largest dark matter overdensities.

Some recent works have investigated the evolution of SMBH spin
and mass from ï¬rst principles, both at high redshift or during the
whole age of the Universe.

Sesana et al. (2014) used a semi-analytical model of galaxy evo-
lution to track the mass and spin evolution of black holes from
high-redshift seeds to the present day. They use several prescriptions
linking the large-scale dynamics of the galaxy to that of the accre-
tion ï¬‚ow on to the SMBH. In all of them, the ï¬‚ow inherits some
memory of the angular momentum of the whole system, leading to
partially aligned accretion. Predictably, then, the calculated SMBH

spin is generally high, especially at high redshift, when gas accretion
is the dominant mode of mass growth. The authors did not set out
to reproduce the observed extreme quasars, but the few examples of
individual SMBH mass and spin evolution show very little growth
in the ï¬rst Gyr after the Big bang. At later times, spin tends to de-
cline somewhat, coming into agreement with available low-redshift
observational constraints.
Griï¬ƒn et al. (2019) use the G

semi-analytical galaxy evo-
lution model to track the mass and spin evolution of black holes.
They use stellar black hole seeds and include mergers and chaotic
cold gas accretion as modes of evolution of SMBH spin. They recover

the present-day SMBH mass function and ï¬nd that SMBHs should
generally have rather low spins

5, but they do not reproduce
the extreme high-redshift quasars. This is most likely because of lim-
ited sample size which only allows them to account for SMBH space
densities

Zhang & Lu (2019) used a model composed of two SMBH growth
phases: an initial super-Eddington coherent phase followed by a
number of Eddington-limited chaotic episodes. During the latter,

the SMBH spin decreases, but the equilibrium values are typically
higher than in our models, mainly due to the somewhat less stringent
constraint on maximum disc mass, which leads to more common
alignment of the disc and the black hole at the early stages of evo-
lution. This led the authors to conclude, in (Zhang et al. 2020), that
a period of super-Eddington growth is necessary to produce the ob-
served high-redshift quasars. In that paper, they added an additional
constraint that the currently-observed Eddington ratio of the high-
redshift quasars is the maximum allowed in the chaotic accretion
periods of SMBH growth, which further constrained the amount of
mass obtained during chaotic accretion episodes. Given that individ-
ual episodes of SMBH growth are short compared to the total growth
time and that the AGN luminosity can vary signiï¬cantly during each
episode, we do not think such a constraint is warranted.

With a simple numerical model, we have shown that extremely mas-
sive black holes, such as PÂ¯oniuÂ¯aâ€™ena , can grow from stellar mass

seeds via luminous accretion. The only necessary assumptions are
that the black hole is fed almost continuously from a turbulent reser-
voir that can produce a large number of accretion episodes with initial
mass transfer rates at least equal to the Eddington rate and initially
uncorrelated directions. This chaotic accretion scenario allows the
black hole to maintain a low spin and, hence, low radiative eï¬ƒ-
ciency

06, which promotes much more rapid growth than the
canonically-assumed

1. There is not much scope for relaxation
of these constraints; in particular, we show that the model would be
falsiï¬ed if a 10

545 Myr after the Big bang. By comparing the observed
space density of extreme quasars with the simulated space density
of Pop-III star formation, we show that only a very small fraction
of seed black holes,

, have to encounter favourable
growth conditions to produce the observed SMBHs at

6. The
other seeds grow much less eï¬ƒciently and result in a population that
is much more diï¬ƒcult to observe both due to lower mass and lower
duty cycle.
